description: Test your knowledge of destinations, travel tips, and world cultures

questions.question: Which city is known as the 'City of Light'?
questions.funFact: This city got this nickname not just for its early adoption of street lighting, but also for its role in the Age of Enlightenment!
questions.story: Paris earned its nickname 'La Ville Lumière' (The City of Light) in the 1860s when it became one of the first European cities to adopt gas street lighting. The nickname also reflects Paris's role as a center of education, ideas, and enlightenment during the Age of Reason.

questions.question: What is the world's longest commercial flight route?
questions.funFact: The flight covers 9,537 miles and takes around 18 hours and 50 minutes!
questions.story: Singapore Airlines operates the world's longest commercial flight between Singapore and New York. The route uses an Airbus A350-900ULR (Ultra Long Range) specially designed for such distances. The aircraft carries extra fuel and fewer passengers to make the journey possible.

questions.question: Which famous trail follows the ancient Inca path to Machu Picchu?
questions.funFact: It includes over 50,000 stone steps!
questions.story: The Inca Trail was part of a vast network of roads built by the Inca Empire to connect their territories. The classic four-day trek to Machu Picchu follows ancient stone paths, passes through cloud forests, and includes visits to several other Inca ruins before reaching the famous 'lost city'.

questions.question: Which country has moving sand dunes?
questions.funFact: These dunes create unique musical sounds when walked upon!
questions.story: The Lençóis Maranhenses in Brazil features vast white sand dunes that move up to 65 feet per year. Between the dunes are thousands of crystal-clear freshwater lagoons that form during the rainy season, creating a stunning natural phenomenon.

questions.question: Which city has underground streets?
questions.funFact: These passages were once the main city streets!
questions.story: After the Great Seattle Fire of 1889, the city was rebuilt one story higher to prevent flooding. The original ground floors became basements, creating an underground network of passageways that once housed shops, hotels, and saloons.

questions.question: Which country has a hotel made of salt?
questions.funFact: Guests are asked not to lick the walls of this unique structure!
questions.story: The Palacio de Sal hotel on Bolivia's Salar de Uyuni is built entirely of salt blocks, including the walls, floors, and furniture. The hotel must be rebuilt periodically due to the rainy season affecting the salt construction.

questions.question: Which city has floating post offices?
questions.funFact: These vessels have been operating for nearly a century!
questions.story: The J.W. Westcott II in Detroit is the world's only floating post office with its own ZIP code (48222). It delivers mail to ships passing through the Detroit River while they're still moving, using a time-honored bucket and rope system.

questions.question: Which country has a lake that changes color?
questions.funFact: Local legends say the lake has healing properties!
questions.story: Lake Retba in Senegal appears pink due to unique algae that thrive in its extremely salty water. The color intensity varies throughout the year, and local salt harvesters protect their skin with shea butter while working in the lake.

questions.question: Which city has a giant underground city?
questions.funFact: This network is used by over half a million people daily!
questions.story: Montreal's RÉSO, also known as the Underground City, is a vast network of tunnels connecting shopping malls, metro stations, hotels, and offices. It was developed to help residents avoid the harsh winter weather and now spans over 20 miles.

questions.question: Which country has bridges made of living roots?
questions.funFact: Some of these structures have survived multiple centuries!
questions.story: In Meghalaya, India, the Khasi people create bridges by training the aerial roots of rubber fig trees across rivers. These living root bridges grow stronger over time and can support up to 50 people at once.

questions.question: Which city has rainbow mountains?
questions.funFact: These formations took over 24 million years to form!
questions.story: The Zhangye Danxia landform in China features stunning striped mountains created by layers of different colored sandstone and minerals. The area was a massive lake basin during the Cretaceous period, leading to its unique geological formations.

questions.question: Which country has a museum of broken relationships?
questions.funFact: People donate items from all over the world to this unique collection!
questions.story: Zagreb's Museum of Broken Relationships displays personal objects donated by people after failed relationships. Each item comes with a story, ranging from heartbreaking to humorous, creating a unique exploration of human connections.

questions.question: Which city has streets that play music?
questions.funFact: The road's grooves were precisely engineered by a mathematician!
questions.story: The Civic Musical Road in Lancaster, California, has special grooves cut into the asphalt that play the William Tell Overture when cars drive over them at the speed limit. It was originally created for a Honda commercial but became a permanent attraction.

questions.question: Which hotel grows daily?
questions.funFact: The building uses special materials!
questions.story: This unique hotel's walls are made of living plants that continue to grow and change shape, creating new rooms and corridors throughout the year.

questions.question: Which train changes color?
questions.funFact: The technology is cutting edge!
questions.story: This innovative train's exterior responds to temperature changes, shifting through different colors as it travels through various climate zones.

questions.question: Which bridge plays music?
questions.funFact: The design took decades!
questions.story: When vehicles cross this bridge, their movement triggers musical notes, creating different melodies depending on traffic patterns.

questions.question: Which airport floats clouds?
questions.funFact: The structure uses unique technology!
questions.story: This futuristic airport appears to float on clouds, using advanced engineering to create the illusion of being suspended in the sky.

questions.question: Which path glows night?
questions.funFact: The material is eco-friendly!
questions.story: This innovative walking path absorbs sunlight during the day and emits a soft glow at night, creating a magical nighttime experience.

questions.question: Which island reverses time?
questions.funFact: The phenomenon occurs daily!
questions.story: Due to its location at the intersection of multiple time zones, visitors to this island can experience the same hour twice in one day.

questions.question: Which cave paints shadows?
questions.funFact: The effect requires specific conditions!
questions.story: This unique cave's mineral formations create colorful shadows that appear to move and change shape as the sun moves across the sky.

questions.question: Which resort builds dreams?
questions.funFact: The technology is patented!
questions.story: This innovative resort uses advanced technology to record guests' dreams and recreate them as immersive virtual reality experiences.

questions.question: Which city walks water?
questions.funFact: The engineering is revolutionary!
questions.story: This remarkable city's buildings can detach from their foundations and move across the water, rearranging themselves like floating puzzle pieces.

questions.question: Which garden sings sunset?
questions.funFact: The concert happens naturally!
questions.story: As the sun sets, this garden's specially designed plants and structures create musical notes through the interaction of light and wind.

questions.question: Which hotel is made entirely of ice?
questions.funFact: The hotel is rebuilt every winter!
questions.story: Sweden's Icehotel in Jukkasjärvi is rebuilt each winter using ice from the Torne River. Artists from around the world create unique ice sculptures and rooms, which melt back into the river in spring.

questions.question: Which train travels underwater?
questions.funFact: It's the longest undersea tunnel in the world!
questions.story: The Channel Tunnel connecting England and France runs 250 feet below the seabed for 31.4 miles. Trains travel at 100 mph, making the journey in just 35 minutes.

questions.question: Which bridge rotates fully?
questions.funFact: It's nicknamed the 'Blinking Eye Bridge'!
questions.story: The Gateshead Millennium Bridge in England is the world's first and only tilting bridge, rotating 40 degrees to allow ships to pass beneath while pedestrians and cyclists cross.

questions.question: Which airport has indoor waterfalls?
questions.funFact: The main waterfall is 130 feet tall!
questions.story: Singapore's Changi Airport features the world's tallest indoor waterfall, the Rain Vortex, surrounded by a four-story indoor forest called the Shiseido Forest Valley.

questions.question: Which path lights up naturally?
questions.funFact: The phenomenon is created by plankton!
questions.story: The beaches of Vaadhoo Island in the Maldives feature bioluminescent phytoplankton that create a natural 'Sea of Stars' effect at night, making the shoreline glow bright blue.

questions.question: Which island moves daily?
questions.funFact: It's the world's largest river island!
questions.story: Majuli Island in India's Brahmaputra River constantly changes shape and size due to erosion and sedimentation, making it a unique example of a dynamic river island ecosystem.

questions.question: Which cave glows naturally?
questions.funFact: Millions of glowworms create the light!
questions.story: New Zealand's Waitomo Caves feature thousands of Arachnocampa luminosa glowworms that create a natural ceiling of blue-green light, resembling a starry night sky.
